msgSnippet: It s unfortunate when you have to test protected methods; however, when you have to do it, this is a good approach. I ve added it to my bag of tricks. Thanks!

It's unfortunate when you have to test protected methods; however, when you=

have to do it, this is a good approach. I've added it to my bag of tricks.=


Thanks!

J. B. Rainsberger  <rainsber@...>

Subject:  [junit] Testing prot=
ected stuff (again)




I hope I manage not to rekinder the flames on the p=
hilosophy of "should I
test protected methods".
I just do. For one, I write=
 test cases on the fly as part of my debugging.
Here's a wee little trick I=
 came across:

public class A {
=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0protected x() {
}

=
public class TextA extends TestCase {
=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0testx()
=A0=
=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0AIntruder ai =3D new AIntruder=
();
=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0ai.testx();
=A0=A0=A0=
=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0}

=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0private static final class AIntru=
der extends A {
=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0public void=
 testx() {
=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=
=A0=A0=A0x();
=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=
=A0=A0=A0=A0assertTrue(internalCondition());
=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=
=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0}
=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0}
}


Happy coding,

- Yishay
